awd_titl_txt: Cross-Scale Spatiotemporal Modeling Using an Integrated Data Framework
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will address the challenges associated with managing scales in space and time within a single, unified analytic framework. The choice of scale is an important question in the analysis of geospatial data. For example, the spatial analysis of socioeconomic variables at the state level may mask local processes taking place at the county or community level. Historically, spatial and temporal analysis has proceeded either separately or in a loosely coupled research design. This project will develop and extend a multi-scale framework for the visualization and analysis of geospatial data. The framework will resolve fundamental issues of scale handling in data analytics, advance knowledge about cross-scale spatio-temporal phenomena, and aid scientists in looking more deeply into the interplay among various environmental and social processes. New tools will be developed and made publicly available. The utility of these tools will be tested in case studies, including an analysis of wetland habitats in coastal Louisiana and Hawaiian rainfall patterns. The project will support graduate students whose participation will advance their own professional development. The collaboration between the University of Hawaii and the University of Colorado at Boulder will increase geographic diversity and the presence of women and underrepresented minorities in computer science, earth science, and spatial data science.

This research project will develop a theoretical framework for multi-scale data representation, modeling, and analysis. Multi-scale analysis of spatio-temporal data is a longstanding concern for analytic systems in many disciplines. The problem of handling scale is epitomized in the well-known modifiable areal unit problem and its temporal equivalent. These issues are partially due to the traditionally held views of time as a linear sequence and space as a flat layer. This project extends research on the Triangular Model (TM), a 2D representation of time, into higher dimensional models. The project will test the utility of TM in analyzing linear spatial data, refine conceptual and computational aspects of a 3D Pyramid Model (PM) for multi-scale spatial analysis, and integrate the TM and PM into an 5D analytical framework for multi-scale spatio-temporal analyses. Topologies, statistics, and machine learning methods will be developed on the models and framework to support multi-scale queries, visualization, and quantitative modeling. The questions to be answered in the project include: 1) what additional knowledge can be gained by analyzing spatio-temporal variations, patterns, and relationships of phenomena across in the TM and PM frameworks? and 2) in what ways can multi-scale representations of spatio-temporal data facilitate the modeling of human-environment interactions?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Summary

Multi-scale analysis has been a longstanding challenge in the field of geography and GIScience. Existing spatial analysis methods primarily focus on a single scale in time and space, and thus may overlook critical relationships and patterns evident across multiple scales. For instance, spatial analysis at the state level may overlook local processes taking place at the county or community levels. Studies of traffic patterns in hourly intervals may obscure seasonal and yearly patterns. To address the challenges of multi-scale analysis, this project extends an innovative 2D time model (the Triangle Model or TM) into a multi-scale modelling framework for spatio-temporal data. The key objectives of this project are: 1) testing the utility of TM in analyzing linear spatial data, 2) refining conceptual and computational aspects of a 3D Pyramid Model (PM) for multi-scale spatial analysis, and 3) integrating the TM and PM into a high-dimensional framework for multi-scale spatio-temporal analyses.

Key Outcomes

Over the course of the project, we achieved several important outcomes:

  1. Utilized the Triangle Model (TM) to analyze the uncertainty of distance measurement on digital terrain surface. The TM allows comparison of distance measurement within different distance intervals and at different resolutions of DEMs, considering distance as a temporal phenomenon and measuring a specified variable as one moves incrementally across a terrain surface. The analysis informs the optimal distance measurement method in specific terrain types, measurement intervals, and data resolutions, thus providing critical information for transportation planning and shortest path vehicle routing.
  2. Developed a suite of analytical tools based on the Pyramid Model to analyze multi-scale patterns in various types of spatial data. First, we developed a 3D visualization tool with interactive controls to support visual exploration of point patterns across spatial scales. Second, we applied the PM to analyze uncertainty of land cover classification at multiple spatial scales.
  3. Applied multi-scale spatial analysis methods to assess flood exposure and disaster recovery. We applied remote sensing images to analyze recovery at the pixel, block group, and city levels during Hurricane Sandy, which revealed the socio-economic disparities of community resilience. We also analyzed the spatio-temporal trends of flood exposure at multiple spatial and temporal scales to evaluate environmental justice of flood risk.

Intellectual Merit:

This project has advanced GIScience by addressing foundational challenges in spatio-temporal analysis. The project provided analytical methods and software tools for analyzing multi-scale patterns in spatio-temporal data. Through case studies, the project demonstrated the practical application of these tools to address domain-specific challenges, including wetland management, vehicle routing, transportation planning, and assessing socio-economic disparities in hazard risk and community resilience.

Broader Impacts:

The project created broad impacts across the academic community, public users, and educators. It supports these communities by developing multi-scale analytical methods that are intuitive and easily understood. The work has been disseminated to target communities through peer-reviewed journal publications, conference presentations and the creation of open-source tools that promote accessibility and reproducibility. The project had an educational impact as it developed comprehensive training resources, including online tutorials, datasets, and source code, to help college instructors and students build hands-on skills in scientific programming and data analytics. Additionally, the project supported five graduate students, contributing to the development of a skilled and diverse STEM workforce.
